newsitem.title: USA: US CORPORATE BONDS-Prices firm ahead of new supply.
newsitem.headline: US CORPORATE BONDS-Prices firm ahead of new supply.

text.p: U.S. corporate bond prices remained firm on Wednesday ahead of a pickup in new issue supply expected later in the week, traders said.
Prices of junk bonds were steady to slightly higher on modest volume on Wednesday. Junk traders reported good buying of media and telecom credits in particular.
Spreads on high-grade corporates were unchanged amid sparse trading, traders said.
Syndicate officials said market demand appeared on track for a series of junk bond offerings as well as a large investment-grade debt deal from Raytheon Co.
In credit-specific news, traders bid up the junk bonds of Apple Computer Inc on news that Microsoft Corp agreed to make a $150 million equity investment in its former computer rival.
Despite the surge in bids, no Apple bonds actually traded, market players said. Traders speculated investors may be waiting for prices to firm or rise even higher before taking profits.
The computer maker's 6.50 percent bonds due 2004 were quoted up 5-1/2 points at 88-92 at the end of the day.

On Wednesday, electric and gas utility, Western Resources sold $520 million in seven- and 12-year first mortgage bonds (A3/BBB-plus) via Dillon Read & Co. The notes are convertible into senior unsecured notes at the discretion of the issuer.
Among junk bond issuers, Mark IV Industries priced $250 million in debt (Ba2/BB-plus) to yield 7.575 percent via Bear Stearns & Co.
Also, B&G Foods priced $120 million in debt (B3/B-minus) to yield 9.625 percent via Lehman Brothers Inc. The deal was increased from an original size of $100 million.
In other markets, the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 71.77 points to end the day at 8259.31.

Treasuries closed higher as the bond market absorbed a Treasury auction of $12 billion in 10-year notes with little trouble. The U.S. Treasury is expected to auction $10 billion in 30-year bonds tomorrow.
The benchmark 30-year bond rose 4/32 to close at 101-28/32. Its yield fell to 6.48 percent.
Among new-issues, Raytheon plans to add a tranche of up to $500 million in three-year debt to its mega-debt offering expected to price on Thursday, sources said.
The new tranche, added to meet strong investor demand, could increase the deal to $3.0 billion from an original size of $2.5 billion.
Relatively few new corporate bond issues priced on Wednesday, although sources said a large calendar is building for later in the week.
